Dual Quaternion Vertex Blending

1. Dual Quaternion

Notations

a \displaystyle a a is a real number
v → \displaystyle \overrightarrow{v} v is a vector in 3D space
q \displaystyle \boldsymbol{q} q is a quaternion
a ^ \displaystyle \hat{a} a^ is a dual number
q ^ \displaystyle \hat{\boldsymbol{q}} q^​ is a dual quaternion

1-1. Quaternion

By "Equation (5.3)" of Quaternions for Computer Graphics, a quaternion can be written as q = w + x i + y j + z k = [ s , v → ] \displaystyle \boldsymbol{q} = w + xi + yj + zk = \begin{bmatrix}s, & \overrightarrow{v}\end{bmatrix} q=w+xi+yj+zk=[s,​v​] where s = w \displaystyle s = w s=w is a real number and v → = [ x , y , z ] \displaystyle \overrightarrow{v} = \begin{bmatrix}x, & y, & z\end{bmatrix} v=[x,​y,​z​] is a vector in 3D space.

1-1-1. Multiplication

By "Equation (5.9)" of Quaternions for Computer Graphics, we have the quaternion multiplication q 0 q 1 = [ s 0 , v 0 → ] [ s 1 , v 1 → ] = [ s 0 s 1 − v 0 → ⋅ v 1 → , s 0 v 1 → + s 1 v 0 → + v 0 → × v 1 → ] \displaystyle \boldsymbol{q_0}\boldsymbol{q_1} = \begin{bmatrix}s_0, & \overrightarrow{v_0}\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}s_1, & \overrightarrow{v_1}\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}s_0 s_1 - \overrightarrow{v_0} \cdot \overrightarrow{v_1}, & s_0 \overrightarrow{v_1} + s_1 \overrightarrow{v_0} + \overrightarrow{v_0} \times \overrightarrow{v_1}\end{bmatrix} q0​q1​=[s0​,​v0​​​][s1​,​v1​​​]=[s0​s1​−v0​​⋅v1​​,​s0​v1​​+s1​v0​​+v0​​×v1​​​].

1-1-2. Conjugation

By "5.12 The Conjugate" of Quaternions for Computer Graphics, we have the quaternion conjugation q ∗ = [ s , v → ] ∗ = [ s , − v → ] {\boldsymbol{q}}^* = {\begin{bmatrix}s, & \overrightarrow{v}\end{bmatrix}}^* = \begin{bmatrix}s, & -\overrightarrow{v}\end{bmatrix} q∗=[s,​v​]∗=[s,​−v​].

1-1-3. Inner Product

By "Equation (22)" of [Kavan 2008], we have that the result of q 0 q ϵ ∗ + q ϵ q 0 ∗ \displaystyle \boldsymbol{q_0} {\boldsymbol{q_\epsilon}}^* + \boldsymbol{q_\epsilon} {\boldsymbol{q_0}}^* q0​qϵ​∗+qϵ​q0​∗ is a real number and can be written as the inner product form q 0 q ϵ ∗ + q ϵ q 0 ∗ = 2 ( s 0 s ϵ + v 0 → ⋅ v ϵ → ) = 2 ( w 0 w ϵ + x 0 x ϵ + y 0 y ϵ + z 0 z ϵ ) = 2 ⟨ q 0 , q ϵ ⟩ \displaystyle \boldsymbol{q_0} {\boldsymbol{q_\epsilon}}^* + \boldsymbol{q_\epsilon} {\boldsymbol{q_0}}^* = 2 (s_0 s_\epsilon + \overrightarrow{v_0} \cdot \overrightarrow{v_\epsilon}) = 2 (w_0 w_\epsilon + x_0 x_\epsilon + y_0 y_\epsilon + z_0 z_\epsilon) = 2 \langle \boldsymbol{q_0}, \boldsymbol{q_\epsilon} \rangle q0​qϵ​∗+qϵ​q0​∗=2(s0​sϵ​+v0​​⋅vϵ​​)=2(w0​wϵ​+x0​xϵ​+y0​yϵ​+z0​zϵ​)=2⟨q0​,qϵ​⟩.

1-1-4. Norm

By "5.12 The Conjugate" of Quaternions for Computer Graphics, we have the norm of a quaternion ∥ q ∥ 2 = q q ∗ = [ s , v → ] [ s , − v → ] = [ s 2 − v → ⋅ ( − v → ) , s ( − v → ) + s v → + v → × ( − v → ) ] = [ s 2 + ∣ v → ∣ 2 , 0 → ] = s 2 + ∣ v → ∣ 2 = w 2 + x 2 + y 2 + z 2 = ⟨ q , q ⟩ ⇒ ∥ q ∥ = ⟨ q , q ⟩ \displaystyle {\| \boldsymbol{q} \|}^2 = \boldsymbol{q} {\boldsymbol{q}}^* = \begin{bmatrix}s, & \overrightarrow{v}\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}s, & -\overrightarrow{v}\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}s^2 - \overrightarrow{v} \cdot (-\overrightarrow{v}), & s (-\overrightarrow{v}) + s \overrightarrow{v} + \overrightarrow{v} \times (-\overrightarrow{v})\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}s^2 + {|\overrightarrow{v}|}^2, & \overrightarrow{0}\end{bmatrix} = s^2 + {|\overrightarrow{v}|}^2 = w^2 + x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = \langle \boldsymbol{q}, \boldsymbol{q} \rangle \Rightarrow \| \boldsymbol{q} \| = \sqrt{\langle \boldsymbol{q}, \boldsymbol{q} \rangle} ∥q∥2=qq∗=[s,​v​][s,​−v​]=[s2−v⋅(−v),​s(−v)+sv+v×(−v)​]=[s2+∣v∣2,​0​]=s2+∣v∣2=w2+x2+y2+z2=⟨q,q⟩⇒∥q∥=⟨q,q⟩​ .

1-1-5. Unit Quaternion

By "5.14 Normalised Quaternion" of Quaternions for Computer Graphics, a unit quaterion is a quaterion of which the norm is 1.

1-1-6. Inverse

By "5.16 Inverse Quaternion" of Quaternions for Computer Graphics, we have the inverse of the quaternion q q − 1 = 1 = [ 1 , 0 → ] ⇒ q ∗ q q − 1 = q ∗ ⇒ ( q ∗ q ) q − 1 = q ∗ ⇒ ∥ q ∥ 2 q − 1 = q ∗ ⇒ q − 1 = q ∗ ∥ q ∥ 2 \displaystyle \boldsymbol{q} {\boldsymbol{q}}^{-1} = 1 = \begin{bmatrix}1, & \overrightarrow{0}\end{bmatrix} \Rightarrow {\boldsymbol{q}}^* \boldsymbol{q} {\boldsymbol{q}}^{-1} = {\boldsymbol{q}}^* \Rightarrow ({\boldsymbol{q}}^* \boldsymbol{q}) {\boldsymbol{q}}^{-1} = {\boldsymbol{q}}^* \Rightarrow {\| \boldsymbol{q} \|}^2 {\boldsymbol{q}}^{-1} = {\boldsymbol{q}}^* \Rightarrow {\boldsymbol{q}}^{-1} = \frac{{\boldsymbol{q}}^*}{{\| \boldsymbol{q} \|}^2} qq−1=1=[1,​0​]⇒q∗qq−1=q∗⇒(q∗q)q−1=q∗⇒∥q∥2q−1=q∗⇒q−1=∥q∥2q∗​.

1-1-7. Bijection between Rotation Transformations and Unit Quaternions

Each rotation transformation can be represented by a unit quaternion. And conversely, each unit quaternion can represent a rotation transformation.

1-1-7-1. Bijection between [axis, angle] and Unit Quaternion

Let p = [ 0 , p → ] \displaystyle \boldsymbol{p} = \begin{bmatrix}0, & \overrightarrow{p}\end{bmatrix} p=[0,​p​​] be the position in 3D space.

Evidently, each unit quaternion can be written as q = [ cos ⁡ θ 2 , sin ⁡ θ 2 n → ] \displaystyle \boldsymbol{q} = \begin{bmatrix}\cos \frac{\theta}{2}, & \sin \frac{\theta}{2} \overrightarrow{n}\end{bmatrix} q=[cos2θ​,​sin2θ​n​] where n → \displaystyle \overrightarrow{n} n is a unit vector in 3D space.

By "1-1-6. Inverse", we have q − 1 = [ cos ⁡ θ 2 , − sin ⁡ θ 2 n → ] ∥ q ∥ 2 = [ cos ⁡ θ 2 , − sin ⁡ θ 2 n → ] \displaystyle {\boldsymbol{q}}^{-1} = \frac{\begin{bmatrix}\cos \frac{\theta}{2}, & - \sin \frac{\theta}{2} \overrightarrow{n}\end{bmatrix}}{{\| \boldsymbol{q} \|}^2} = \begin{bmatrix}\cos \frac{\theta}{2}, & - \sin \frac{\theta}{2} \overrightarrow{n}\end{bmatrix} q−1=∥q∥2[cos2θ​,​−sin2θ​n​]​=[cos2θ​,​−sin2θ​n​]

By "1-1-1. Multiplication", we have p ′ = q p q − 1 = [ cos ⁡ θ 2 , sin ⁡ θ 2 n → ] [ 0 , p → ] [ cos ⁡ θ 2 , − sin ⁡ θ 2 n → ] = [ 0 , ( 1 − cos ⁡ θ ) ( n → ⋅ p → ) p → + cos ⁡ θ p → + sin ⁡ θ n → × p → ] \displaystyle \boldsymbol{p'} = \boldsymbol{q} \boldsymbol{p} {\boldsymbol{q}}^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix}\cos \frac{\theta}{2}, & \sin \frac{\theta}{2} \overrightarrow{n}\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}0, & \overrightarrow{p}\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}\cos \frac{\theta}{2}, & - \sin \frac{\theta}{2} \overrightarrow{n}\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}0, & (1 - \cos \theta) (\overrightarrow{n} \cdot \overrightarrow{p}) \overrightarrow{p} + \cos \theta \overrightarrow{p} + \sin \theta \overrightarrow{n} \times \overrightarrow{p}\end{bmatrix} p′=qpq−1=[cos2θ​,​sin2θ​n​][0,​p​​][cos2θ​,​−sin2θ​n​]=[0,​(1−cosθ)(n⋅p​)p​+cosθp​+sinθn×p​​]. The lengthy calculation is provided by "Equation (7.13)" of Quaternions for Computer Graphics.

Let p ′ = q p q − 1 = [ 0 , p ′ → ] \displaystyle \boldsymbol{p'} = \boldsymbol{q} \boldsymbol{p} {\boldsymbol{q}}^{-1} = [0, \overrightarrow{p'}] p′=qpq−1=[0,p′​] where p ′ → = ( 1 − cos ⁡ θ ) ( v → ⋅ p → ) p → + cos ⁡ 2 θ p → + sin ⁡ 2 θ v → × p → \displaystyle \overrightarrow{p'} = (1 - \cos \theta) (\overrightarrow{v} \cdot \overrightarrow{p}) \overrightarrow{p} + \cos 2 \theta \overrightarrow{p} + \sin 2 \theta \overrightarrow{v} \times \overrightarrow{p} p′​=(1−cosθ)(v⋅p​)p​+cos2θp​+sin2θv×p​ is the position after the transform in 3D space.

By "Fig. 6.7" and "Fig. 6.8" of Quaternions for Computer Graphics, we have p ′ → \displaystyle \overrightarrow{p'} p′​ is the position where p → \displaystyle \overrightarrow{p} p​ is rotated about the axis n → \displaystyle \overrightarrow{n} n by the angle θ \displaystyle \theta θ.

1-1-7-2. Mapping from Rotation Transformations to Unit Quaternions

By "Conversion from rotation matrix to axis–angle" of Rotation matrix in Wikipedia, we can deduce the axis and the angle from the rotation matrix. The main idea is that the axis is an eigenvector of the matrix and the angle can be deduced from trace of the rotation matrix.

Once we have the axis and the angle, by "1-1-7-1. Bijection between [axis, angle] and Unit Quaternion", we can have the quaternion.

The implementation is provided by XMQuaternionRotationMatrix of DirectXMath.

1-1-7-3. Mapping from Unit Quaternions to Rotation Transformations

1-2. Dual Numbder

By "A.1 Dual Numbers" of [Kavan 2008], a dual number can be written as a ^ = a 0 + a ϵ ϵ \displaystyle \hat{a} = a_0 + a_\epsilon \epsilon a^=a0​+aϵ​ϵ, where a 0 \displaystyle a_0 a0​ and a ϵ \displaystyle a_\epsilon aϵ​ are real numbers, and ϵ \displaystyle \epsilon ϵ is a basis such that 1   ϵ = ϵ   1 = ϵ \displaystyle 1 \, \epsilon = \epsilon \, 1 = \epsilon 1ϵ=ϵ1=ϵ and ϵ   ϵ = 0 \epsilon \,\epsilon = 0 ϵϵ=0.

1-2-1. Multiplication

By "Equation (17)" of [Kavan 2008], we have the dual number multiplication a ^ b ^ = ( a 0 + a ϵ ϵ ) ( b 0 + b ϵ ϵ ) = a 0 b 0 + ( a 0 b ϵ + b 0 a ϵ ) ϵ \displaystyle \hat{a} \hat{b} = (a_0 + a_\epsilon \epsilon)(b_0 + b_\epsilon \epsilon) = a_0 b_0 + (a_0 b_\epsilon + b_0 a_\epsilon) \epsilon a^b^=(a0​+aϵ​ϵ)(b0​+bϵ​ϵ)=a0​b0​+(a0​bϵ​+b0​aϵ​)ϵ.

1-2-2. Conjugation

By "A.1 Dual Numbers" of [Kavan 2008], we have the dual number conjugation a ^ ‾ = a 0 + a ϵ ϵ ‾ = a 0 − a ϵ ϵ \displaystyle \overline{\hat{a}} = \overline{a_0 + a_\epsilon \epsilon} = a_0 - a_\epsilon \epsilon a^=a0​+aϵ​ϵ​=a0​−aϵ​ϵ.

2-3. Square Root

If a 0 > 0 a_0 \gt 0 a0​>0, then a 0 + a ϵ ϵ = a 0 + a ϵ 2 a 0 ϵ \sqrt{a_0 + a_\epsilon\epsilon} = \sqrt{a_0} + \frac{a_\epsilon}{2\sqrt{a_0}}\epsilon a0​+aϵ​ϵ​=a0​​+2a0​​aϵ​​ϵ ([Kavan 2008] / A Dual Quaternion Tutorial / A.1 Dual Numbers / Lemma 8).
Proof:
We assume that there exists the dual number b 0 + b ϵ ϵ b_0 + b_\epsilon\epsilon b0​+bϵ​ϵ such that a 0 + a ϵ ϵ = ( b 0 + b ϵ ϵ ) ( b 0 + b ϵ ϵ ) a_0 + a_\epsilon\epsilon = (b_0 + b_\epsilon\epsilon)(b_0 + b_\epsilon\epsilon) a0​+aϵ​ϵ=(b0​+bϵ​ϵ)(b0​+bϵ​ϵ), namely, a 0 + a ϵ ϵ = b 0 + b ϵ ϵ \sqrt{a_0 + a_\epsilon\epsilon} = b_0 + b_\epsilon\epsilon a0​+aϵ​ϵ​=b0​+bϵ​ϵ.
Evidently, we have b 0 b 0 = a 0 b_0b_0 = a_0 b0​b0​=a0​ and 2 b 0 b ϵ = a ϵ 2b_0b_\epsilon = a_\epsilon 2b0​bϵ​=aϵ​ . And thus, if a 0 > 0 a_0 \gt 0 a0​>0, we have b 0 = a 0 b_0 = \sqrt{a_0} b0​=a0​​ and b ϵ = a ϵ 2 a 0 b_\epsilon = \frac{a_\epsilon}{2\sqrt{a_0}} bϵ​=2a0​​aϵ​​.

3. Dual Quaternion

By "A.2 Dual Quaternions" of [Kavan 2008], a dual quaternion can be deemed not only a quaternion whose elements are dual numbers, but also a dual number whose elements are quaternions. This means that we have not only q ^ = q w ^ + q x ^ i + q y ^ j + q z ^ k \displaystyle \hat{\boldsymbol{q}} = \hat{q_w} + \hat{q_x}i + \hat{q_y}j + \hat{q_z}k q^​=qw​^​+qx​^​i+qy​^​j+qz​^​k where q w ^ \displaystyle \hat{q_w} qw​^​ , q x ^ \displaystyle \hat{q_x} qx​^​ , q y ^ \displaystyle \hat{q_y} qy​^​ and q z ^ \displaystyle \hat{q_z} qz​^​ are dual numbers, but also q ^ = q 0 + q ϵ ϵ \displaystyle \hat{\boldsymbol{q}} = \boldsymbol{q_0} + \boldsymbol{q_\epsilon}\epsilon q^​=q0​+qϵ​ϵ where q 0 \displaystyle \boldsymbol{q_0} q0​ and q ϵ \displaystyle \boldsymbol{q_\epsilon} qϵ​ are quaternions.

3-1. Multiplication

p ^ q ^ = ( p 0 + p ϵ ϵ ) ( q 0 + q ϵ ϵ ) = p 0 q 0 + ( p 0 q ϵ + p ϵ q 0 ) ϵ \displaystyle \hat{\boldsymbol{p}}\hat{\boldsymbol{q}} = (\boldsymbol{p_0} + \boldsymbol{p_\epsilon}\epsilon)(\boldsymbol{q_0} + \boldsymbol{q_\epsilon}\epsilon) = \boldsymbol{p_0}\boldsymbol{q_0} + (\boldsymbol{p_0}\boldsymbol{q_\epsilon} + \boldsymbol{p_\epsilon}\boldsymbol{q_0})\epsilon p^​q^​=(p0​+pϵ​ϵ)(q0​+qϵ​ϵ)=p0​q0​+(p0​qϵ​+pϵ​q0​)ϵ where p 0 q 0 \displaystyle \boldsymbol{p_0}\boldsymbol{q_0} p0​q0​ , p 0 q ϵ \displaystyle \boldsymbol{p_0}\boldsymbol{q_\epsilon} p0​qϵ​ and p ϵ q 0 \displaystyle \boldsymbol{p_\epsilon}\boldsymbol{q_0} pϵ​q0​ follow the rule of the multiplication of two ordinary quaternions ([Kavan 2008] / A Dual Quaternion Tutorial / A.2 Dual Quaternions).

3-2. Conjugation

3-2-1. First Type of Conjugation - Quaternion Style

By "A.2 Dual Quaternions" of [Kavan 2008], we have the quaternion style conjugation q ^ ∗ = ( q 0 + q ϵ ϵ ) ∗ = q 0 ∗ + q ϵ ∗ ϵ \displaystyle {\hat{\boldsymbol{q}}}^* = {(\boldsymbol{q_0} + \boldsymbol{q_\epsilon} \epsilon)}^* = {\boldsymbol{q_0}}^* + {{\boldsymbol{q_\epsilon}}^*} \epsilon q^​∗=(q0​+qϵ​ϵ)∗=q0​∗+qϵ​∗ϵ.

3-2-2. Second Type of Conjugation - Dual Number Style

By "A.2 Dual Quaternions" of [Kavan 2008], we have the dual number style conjugation q ^ ‾ = q 0 + q ϵ ϵ ‾ = q 0 − q ϵ ϵ \displaystyle \overline{\hat{\boldsymbol{q}}} = \overline{\boldsymbol{q_0} + \boldsymbol{q_\epsilon} \epsilon} = \boldsymbol{q_0} - \boldsymbol{q_\epsilon} \epsilon q^​​=q0​+qϵ​ϵ​=q0​−qϵ​ϵ.

3-2-3. Commutative Property

By "A.2 Dual Quaternions" of [Kavan 2008], since q ^ ∗ ‾ = ( q 0 + q ϵ ϵ ) ∗ ‾ = q 0 ∗ + q ϵ ∗ ϵ ‾ = q 0 ∗ − q ϵ ∗ ϵ = ( q 0 − q ϵ ϵ ) ∗ = ( q 0 + q ϵ ϵ ‾ ) ∗ = q ^ ‾ ∗ \displaystyle \overline{{\hat{\boldsymbol{q}}}^*} = \overline{{(\boldsymbol{q_0} + \boldsymbol{q_\epsilon} \epsilon)}^*} = \overline{{\boldsymbol{q_0}}^* + {{\boldsymbol{q_\epsilon}}^*} \epsilon} = {\boldsymbol{q_0}}^* - {{\boldsymbol{q_\epsilon}}^*} \epsilon = {(\boldsymbol{q_0} - \boldsymbol{q_\epsilon} \epsilon)}^* = {(\overline{\boldsymbol{q_0} + \boldsymbol{q_\epsilon} \epsilon})}^* = {\overline{\hat{\boldsymbol{q}}}}^* q^​∗​=(q0​+qϵ​ϵ)∗​=q0​∗+qϵ​∗ϵ​=q0​∗−qϵ​∗ϵ=(q0​−qϵ​ϵ)∗=(q0​+qϵ​ϵ​)∗=q^​​∗ , we have q ^ ∗ ‾ = q ^ ‾ ∗ = q 0 ∗ − q ϵ ∗ ϵ \overline{{\hat{\boldsymbol{q}}}^*} = {\overline{\hat{\boldsymbol{q}}}}^* = {\boldsymbol{q_0}}^* - {{\boldsymbol{q_\epsilon}}^*} \epsilon q^​∗​=q^​​∗=q0​∗−qϵ​∗ϵ.
